Event |- | 1939-11-02 | [[Oslo Report]] |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] German scientist [[Hans Ferdinand Mayer]] anonymously sent information and a sample of German technology to the British embassy in Oslo. He warned the British of current German technology including radar and planned German secret weapons such as rockets and winged missiles. Reception of the report was mixed with some believing it to be misdirection. Some of the information was second-hand and proved to be incorrect. "Head of the Scientific Section of [[Secret Intelligence Service|M.I.6]]". |- |1941 |Peenemünde |German scientist/editor [[Paul Rosbaud]] and Norwegian engineering student/[[XU]] agent [[Sverre Bergh]] submitted the first detailed description of the Peenemünde facilities and size/shape of missiles to British intelligence. Their reports were largely ignored until corroborated in 1943.{{Cite book|title=Griffen - den største spionhistorien|last=Kramish|first=Arnold|publisher=J. W. Cappelens Forlag|year=1987|isbn=82-02-10743-1|location=Oslo|pages=|via=}}{{Cite book|title=Spion i Hitlers Rike|last=Bergh|first=Sverre|publisher=Cappelen|year=2006|isbn=9788204123619|location=Oslo|pages=|via=}} |- | 1942-05-15 | [[Peenemünde Army Research Center|Peenemünde]]: [[Test Stand VII|P-7]] |{{sort|PR1942-05-15|}}[[File:RAF roundel.svg|12px]] The Peenemunde research centre was photographed by a reconnaissance Spitfire. The photographs{{cite book |last=Ordway |first=Frederick I, III |authorlink=Frederick I. Ordway III |author2=Sharpe, Mitchell R |year=1979 |title=The Rocket Team |url=http://www.apogeebooks.com/indices/RocketTeamindex.htm |format=index |series=Apogee Books Space Series 36 |publisher=Thomas Y. Crowell |location=New York |pages=57,114,117,174b-e,251,258d |isbn=1-894959-00-0 |access-date=2012-03-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304025247/http://www.apogeebooks.com/indices/RocketTeamindex.htm |archive-date=2012-03-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}{{Rp|114}} showed "unusual" circular embankments ([[Test Stand VII]] but these were "dismissed". |- | 1943-01-19 | Peenemünde |{{sort|PR1943-01-19|}}[[File:US flag 48 stars.svg|20px]] The US requested photoreconnaissance of [[Usedom]] island.{{Rp|61}} |- | 1943-03-22 | |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] [[Wilhelm Ritter von Thoma]], a General captured in North Africa was secretly recorded while in a British prison. In conversation with another fellow prisoner-of-war he disclosed he had seen the launch of a "huge" rocket{{Rp|333}} circa 1936-7. |- | 1943-04-22 | Peenemünde: P-7 |{{sort|PR1943-04-22|}}[[File:RAF roundel.svg|12px]] [[de Havilland Mosquito]] ''DZ473'' was carrying out [[bomb damage assessment]] on [[History of Szczecin#In the Third Reich (1933-1945)|Stettin]]. On leaving Stettin, they left their cameras "running all down the north coast of Germany." The photograph interpreters at [[RAF Medmenham]] noticed an object of {{convert|25|ft|m|abbr=on}}{{Rp|16}} —an "enormous cloud of steam" that had disappeared 4 seconds later in the subsequent image.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} The "object" was both the cooling steam from leaky flame deflector pipes and the flames of a V-2 motor at the end of a test{{Rp|339,433}} being directed horizontally by the P-7 flame trenches. |- | {{sort|1943-05-15|1943-05}} | Peenemünde |{{sort|US|}}[[File:US flag 48 stars.svg|20px]] The senior US intelligence representative in Switzerland ([[Allen Dulles]]) identified Peenemünde to the US.{{Rp|143}} In 1943, agent "[[Fritz Kolbe|George Wood]]" began providing Dulles with intelligence.{{Specify|reason=THE Fritz Kolbe WIKIARTICLE MAKES THIS CLAIM BUT DOESN'T IDENTIFY A SPECIFIC PIECE OF INTEL|date=March 2010}} |- | 1943-05-17 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] [[Blockhaus d'Éperlecques|Watten]] |{{sort|PR1943-05-17|}}[[File:RAF roundel.svg|12px]] After an agent had reported "enormous trenches" at Watten during April, photoreconnaissance showed the [[Nord-Pas-de-Calais#History|Nord-Pas-de-Calais]] site was "a large rail-, and canal-served clearing in the woods, possibly a gravel pit."{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} [[File:US roundel 1942-1943.svg|12px]] The Watten blockhouse which was being constructed for launching V-2s was bombed for the first time on August 27 as a suspected [[V-1 flying bomb]] site. |- | 1943-05-14 | Peenemünde: P-7 |{{sort|PR1943-05-14|}} Two sorties photographed an "unusually high level of activity" at "the Ellipse" (the Reich Director of Manpower was visiting for a V-2 test launch).{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}{{Rp|58}} |- | 1943-06-04 | Peenemünde |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] [[R.V. Jones]] received a [[Luxembourger]]'s smuggled sketch of northwestern [[Usedom]] island via the "[[Famille Martin]]" network.. Also in June, agent [[Leon Henri Roth]] at Peenemünde reported "development of a large rocket which made a noise resembling that of 'a squadron at low altitude." Foreign [[forced labor]]ers of the V-2 test center were housed at Camp [[Trassenheide]], and two reports beginning in June from the camp (sent via Spain) identified the "rocket assembly hall", "experimental pit", and "launching tower".{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}{{Rp|139}} |- | 1943-06-12 | {{nowrap|Peenemünde: P-7}} |{{sort|PR1943-06-12|}}[[File:RAF roundel.svg|12px]] Mosquito PR sortie N/853{{Rp|41}} showed: "a white-[[:wiktionary:-ish|ish]] cylinder about 35 feet long and 5 or so feet in diameter with fins" (R.V. Jones){{Rp|300c,340}} |- | 1943-06-22 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] A disgruntled officer in a [[Oberkommando der Wehrmacht|German High Command]] weapons department reported "winged' missiles… Thirty catapults had been constructed…fifteen were already serviceable."{{Rp|338}}
[[File:Roundel of the German Air Force (with Border).svg|12px]]At [[Peenemünde Airfield|Peenemünde-West]] on December 24, 1942, the first ramp-launched [[V-1 flying bomb|V-1]] traveled 3,000 yards{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}{{Rp|25}}{{Rp|18}} and was the first flight powered by the [[Argus As 014]] [[pulse jet engine]].{{cite book |last=Pocock|first= Rowland F|title=German Guided Missiles of the Second World War|year=1967 |publisher=Arco Publishing Company, Inc |location=New York |isbn= |page=22}} |- | 1943-06-23 | Peenemünde: P-7 |{{sort|PR1943-06-23|}}[[File:RAF roundel.svg|12px]] PR by a [[No. 540 Squadron RAF]] Mosquito PR.4 showed two V-2s{{cite book |last=Cooksley |first=Peter G |year=1979 |title=Flying Bomb |location=New York |publisher=Charles Scribner’s Sons |pages=44,53,56,81,157}}{{Rp|53}} which were identified by interpreter André Kenny.{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1351907/Constance-Babington-Smith.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | title=Constance Babington Smith | date=2000-08-09}} |- | 1943-06-29 | Peenemünde |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] Churchill and the [[Bombing of Peenemünde in World War II#Cabinet Defence Committee (Operations)|Cabinet Defence Committee (Operations)]] reviewed V-2 intelligence: "Peenemünde is … beyond the range of our radio navigation beams and … we must bomb by moonlight, although the German night fighters will be close at hand and it is too far to send our own. Nevertheless, we must attack it on the heaviest possible scale." {{cite web |title=The V2 rocket: A romance with the future |url=http://www.makingthemodernworld.org.uk/stories/defiant_modernism/01.ST.03/?scene=9&tv=true |work=Science in war |publisher=The Science Museum |year=2004 |accessdate=2008-09-22 }} |- | 1943-07-26 | Peenemünde |{{sort|PR1943-07-26|}}[[File:RAF roundel.svg|12px]] Mosquito PR prior to the Hydra attack detected new anti-aircraft guns and a row of six smoke generators.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}{{Rp|82}} |- | 1943-08-16 | Peenemünde |Two days prior to the [[Operation Hydra (1943)|Operation Hydra]] attack on the scientists quarters, workshops, and experimental facilities, a [[Westland Lysander]] picked up French agent Lèon Faye who carried "a detailed report of the top secret V-weapon rocket development at Peenemünde" to England.{{cite book |last=Verity |first=Hugh |authorlink=Hugh Verity |title=We Landed by Moonlight |page=118}} (cited by Middlebrook p. 39) |- | 1943-08-22 | Denmark |An air-launched test of an overfuelled V-1 from the "G.A.F. Research Center, Karlshagen" (Peenemunde),{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} [[Bornholm#History|crashed on Bornholm]], and [[:de:Hasager Christiansen|Hasager Christiansen]] obtained photos of the automatic pilot, compressed air cylinder, main fuselage and wings before the German recovery team arrived. |- | 1943-09 | Peenemünde: P-7 |PR showed P-7 bomb craters,{{Rp|174e}} but Peenemünde personnel had fabricated post-Hydra bomb damage by creating craters in the sand, by blowing-up lightly damaged and minor buildings, and by painting "black and white lines to simulate charred beams".{{cite book |last=Middlebrook|first=Martin|authorlink=|title=The Peenemünde Raid: The Night of 17–18 August 1943|year=1982|publisher=Bobs-Merrill|location=New York|pages=39, 41, 198}}{{Rp|198}} Research and development on the V-2 continued promptly despite Operation Hydra, and the next V-2 test launch was 49 days later. |- | 1943-09-07 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] An [[Ultra]] intercept identified that an agent tasked with gathering rocket intelligence had been captured ([[Jeannie Rousseau|Amniarix]] survived the war). |- | 1943-09-19 | |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] The '''Questionnaire…to establish the practicability…of the German Long-Range Rocket''' was distributed regarding the interpretation of V-2 intelligence:{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}{{Rp|131}} "''it is not without precedent for the Germans to have succeeded while we doubted: [[Battle of the Beams|the beams]] are a sufficient example.''" (September 25, R. V. Jones) vs. "''at the end of the war, when we knew the full story we should find that the ''[60 ton]'' rocket was a [[wiktionary:mare's nest|mare's nest]]''" (October 25, [[Frederick Lindemann, 1st Viscount Cherwell|Lord Cherwell]]).{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}{{Rp|3,159}} |- | 1943-09-28 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] [[V-3 cannon]] |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] The [[Central Interpretation Unit]] issued a report on the Marquise-Mimoyecques site ([[File:US roundel 1942-1943.svg|12px]]1st bombed November 5 as a suspected V-2 launch bunker).{{Citation needed|reason=THE V-3 Cannon WIKIARTICLE MAKES THE SAME CLAIM WITHOUT CITATION|date=March 2010}} |- | 1943-09-30 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] |{{sort|PR1943-09-30|}} 133 V-weapon facilities had been photographed by the [[No. 1 Photographic Reconnaissance Unit RAF|PRU]] {{cite book |last=Bowman |first=Martin W |title=Mosquito Photo-Reconnaissance Units of World War 2 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Gx85T-eYPdQC&pg=PA19 |format=Google Books |page=18}} including [[V-1 flying bomb (facilities)#V-1 storage depots|V-1 flying bomb storage depots]] in Occupied France under construction since August.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}{{Rp|194}} (They were not used for the modified sites.) |- | 1943-09 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] After a [[Réseau AGIR]] informant reported{{When|date=February 2010}} unusual construction in [[Upper Normandy]],{{Specify|WHICH SITE?|date=February 2010}} [[Michel Hollard]] smuggled a report via Switzerland that identified 6 [[V-1 flying bomb (facilities)|V-1 sites]].{{Rp|3}} |- | 1943-10 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] [[Yvrench|Bois Carré]] |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] The Réseau AGIR reported the Bois Carré V-1 site (1.4 km east of Yvrench){{cite web |title=V1, V2 & V3 |url=http://www.christianch.ch/history/v1_v2_v3.htm |publisher=christianCH.ch |accessdate=2010-02-11|language=de}} had "''a concrete platform with centre axis pointing directly to London''".{{Rp|300e,360}} The network reconnoitered 104{{cite web |date=26 April 2004 |title=Eurostar remembers Michel Hollard |url=http://google.com/search?q=cache:qFHenfkBwwUJ:www.atoc-comms.org/dynamic/toc-press-story/257320/Eurostar-remembers-Michel-Hollard-160-160-the-man-who-saved-London+atoc+hollard+v-1&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us |accessdate=2010-03-15}} V-1 facilities and provided rough sketches such as one by '''André Comps''' of Bois Carré. {{Cite magazine |last= |first= |year=1974 |title=The V-Weapons |url=http://www.afterthebattle.com/ab-con1.html#index |magazine=After The Battle |pages=3, 14, 16|access-date=2007-12-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090312065112/http://www.afterthebattle.com/ab-con1.html#index |archive-date=2009-03-12 |dead-url=yes |df= }}{{Rp|3}} Comps copied the blueprints after Hollard had him infiltrate the site as a [[draughtsman]]. |- | 1943-10-03 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] [[Siracourt V-1 bunker|Siracourt]] |{{sort|RAF|}}[[File:RAF roundel.svg|12px]] [[List of Royal Air Force aircraft squadrons|No. 542 Squadron RAF]] photographed the Siracourt bunker ([[File:US roundel 1942-1943.svg|12px]]1st bombed January 31, 1944). |- | {{sort|1943-10-20|1943 autumn}} | |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] The PR image of a {{Convert|40|x|7|ft|m|abbr=on}} object with {{sic|"three}} fins" and a blunt nose (later identified as a V-2 without warhead) was code named ''Bodyline''.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}{{Rp|149}} |- | 1943-10-21 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] |{{sort|PR1943-10-21|}}PR was ordered for the whole of [[German occupation of France during World War II|Northern France]].{{Rp|36}} |- | 1943-10-28 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] Bois Carré |{{sort|PR1943-11-03|}}[[File:RAF roundel.svg|12px]] PR by Plt Off R A Hosking in Mosquito LR424{{Rp|18}} of [[No. 540 Squadron RAF]] was the first to show "''ski-shaped buildings''" at the Bois Carré (Yvrench) site.{{cite book |last=Sharp |first=C. Martin |author2=Bowyer, Michael J. F. |year=1971 |title=Mosquito |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iogeAQAACAAJ |publisher=Faber & Faber |location=London |page=132 |isbn=0-85979-115-7}}{{Rp|132}} |- | 1943-11-03 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] Bois Carré |{{sort|PR1943-11-03|}}[[File:RAF roundel.svg|12px]] PR by Mosquito on [[No. 541 Squadron RAF]] sortie E/463{{cite web |last= |first= |title=Operation Crossbow - V1 Bois Carré Sites |url=http://aerial.rcahms.gov.uk/006-008-000-695-C |work=The National Collection of Aerial Photography |publisher=Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments of Scotland |accessdate=2011-12-26}} confirmed existence of a concrete platform with axis pointing directly towards London, as informed by an agent infiltrating the Bois Carré (Yvrench) construction site.{{Rp|300e}} |- | 1943-11-28 | [[Peenemünde Airfield|Peenemünde-West]] |{{sort|PR1943-11-28|}}[[File:RAF roundel.svg|12px]] Mosquito PR by Sqn Ldr Merrifield and F/O Whalley{{Rp|18}} (scheduled by Jones for a likely V-1 launch time), photographed a "midget aircraft" on the ramp at the edge of the Peenemünde-West airfield, which Babington-Smith detected on December 1. An additional ramp was between [[Zinnowitz]] and [[Zempin]], and the small aircraft was [[code name]]d 'Peenemünde 20'.{{Rp|44}} |- | 1943-11 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] |{{sort|PR1943-11|}}72 "ski sites" had been photographed.{{Rp|184}} |- | 1943-12-04 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] |{{sort|PR1943-12-04|}}PR was again conducted across [[Northern France]]{{Rp|3}} just before the December 5 start of "''[[Operation Crossbow|Crossbow Operations Against Ski Sites]]''", which the [[Combined Chiefs of Staff]] authorized on December 2. [[File:US roundel 1942-1943.svg|12px]]The [[Ninth Air Force]] conducted [[V-1 flying bomb (facilities)#V-1 launching sites|the first attack]] (3 sites at [[Ligescourt]]), and the 1st major strike on ski sites by [[VIII Bomber Command]] was December 24. |- | 1943-12-04 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] 'Druides' agent Amniarix ('''Jeannie Rousseau''') reported the V-1 organization was moving and being renamed from [[Flak corps|Flak Regiment]] 155W to Flak Gruppe [[Creil]]. |- |1944-01-04 | [[The Pentagon]]

[[Operation Crossbow Site|Eglin Field]] |{{sort|UKUS|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] [[File:US flag 48 stars.svg|20px]] [[William Napier, 13th Lord Napier|Brigadier Napier]] of the [[Ministry of Supply#World War II|Ministry of Supply]] briefed the [[Military history of the United States during World War II#European and North African Theaters|US military]] regarding German long range weapon intelligence, and [[General Ismay]] directed reports be shared with the US.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} The US "Crossbow Committee" under General Stephen Henry of the New Developments Division {{cite book |last=Zaloga |first=Steven J. |origyear=2007 |year=2008 |others= |title=German V-Weapon Sites 1943-45 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AkRnX4zUwAAC |format=Google Books |location=New York |publisher=Osprey Publishing Ltd |series=[[Fortress Study Group]] (72) |isbn=978-1-84603-247-9 |pages=3, 25, 29, 31–2, 42, 46, 75}}{{Rp|29}} first met on January 6 after forming on December 29. In February and March, the US used [[technical intelligence]] data to build [[Operation Crossbow Site|full-size replicas of ski site buildings]] to plan bombing tactics.{{Rp|29}} |- | 1944-02 | Peenemunde: P-7 |{{sort|PR1944-02|}}PR showed roads north of the ellipse that matched roadways later discovered after the [[Normandy Invasion]] at the [[Le Molay-Littry|Château de Molay]] V-2 site. |- | 1944-02-25 | |{{sort|Z|}}[[File:Flag of Germany 1933.svg|20px]] The 1st transportable V-1 catapult ramp was ready (95 were ready by the end of March).{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}{{Rp|194}} Ramp sections built by the [[Hellmuth Walter|HWK]] in Kiel were hidden from PR until enough V-1s were ready for an initial assault. An October 22/23, 1943, [[Area bombing directive|area bombing]] had [[Bombing of Kassel in World War II|wrecked Kassel homes]] of [[Fieseler]] workers, delaying their transfer to the new V-1 plant at [[Rothwesten]] and as a result, delaying "''the final trials of the ''[V-1]'' weapon's power unit, control-gear, diving mechanism, compass and air-log''" until February{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} and production for "three or four" months.{{cite book |last=D'Olier |first=Franklin |author2=Alexander |author3=Ball |author4=Bowman |author5=Galbraith |author6=Likert |author7=McNamee |author8=Nitze |author9=Russell |author10=Searls |author11=Wright |date=September 30, 1945 |chapter=The Secondary Campaigns |chapter-url=http://www.usaaf.net/surveys/eto/ebs14.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516090317/http://www.usaaf.net/surveys/eto/ebs14.htm |archive-date=2008-05-16 |title=United States Strategic Bombing Survey, Summary Report (European War) |accessdate=2008-09-22}} ([https://web.archive.org/web/20080528051903/http://aupress.au.af.mil/Books/USSBS/USSBS.pdf Alternate version]) (cited by Mets p. 239, which has the "three or four" numbers) |- | 1944-03 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] |{{sort|Z|}}[[File:Flag of Germany 1933.svg|20px]] A plan for underground concealment of a total of 5000 V-1s to supply 8 depots (each holding 250 more for the modified launchers){{citation needed|date=March 2013}} was initiated for [[Nucourt]]'s limestone caves, [[Rilly-la-Montagne]]'s rail tunnel, and [[Saint-Leu-d'Esserent]]'s mushroom caves.{{Rp|426}} Also in March, the [[Brécourt]] [[V-2]] bunker was ordered to be converted to a V-1 bunker. |- | 1944-03 | [[Polish areas annexed by Nazi Germany|Poland]] |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] [[File:Flag of Poland.svg|20px]] [[Secret Intelligence Service|Intelligence headquarters]] received a [[Home Army and V1 and V2|Polish report]] of "''an object which, though covered by a tarpaulin, bore every resemblance to a monstrous torpedo''" on a [[Blizna]] railroad car that was heavily guarded by [[Schutzstaffel|SS troops]].{{Rp|42}} The [[List of V-2 test launches#Blizna test launch list|first V-2 training launch at Blizna]] had been on November 5, 1943,{{Citation needed|date=April 2013}} after Major Weber's experimental staff at [[Köslin]] and Experimental Battery 444 transferred to Blizna at the end of October. {{cite book |last=Dornberger|first=Walter|authorlink=Walter Dornberger|others=translated by James Cleugh and Geoffrey Halliday |year=1954 |origyear=1952: V2--Der Schuss ins Weltall |title=V-2 |publisher=Viking Press |location=New York |isbn=0-553-12660-1|edition=1979 Bantam |page=214}} In May, the 953 (Semi-Mobile) Artillery Detachment started Abteilungen ({{lang-en|firing detachment}}) training at Blizna for operations at [[La Coupole|Wizernes]],{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} and Ultra decoded [[Enigma machine|Enigma messages]] about the transfer to Blizna.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} |- | 1944-04-22 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] |{{sort|US|}}[[File:US flag 48 stars.svg|20px]] The Crossbow Committee issued a revised ski site diagram based on a January 20 sketch. [[File:RAF roundel.svg|12px]][[File:US roundel 1942-1943.svg|12px]]By the end of March, Anglo-American attacks had destroyed nine ski sites and seriously damaged 35 more.{{Rp|31}} On April 19 at the request of the [[Churchill War Ministry|War Cabinet]], General [[Dwight D. Eisenhower|Eisenhower]] had designated [[Operation Crossbow|Crossbow targets]] as the highest priority for the [[Combined Bomber Offensive]]. |- | 1944-04-26 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] "[[Arrondissement of Cherbourg|Belhamelin]], near [[Cotentin Peninsula|Cherbourg]]" |{{sort|PR1944-04-26|}}PR identified{{Specify|RAF OR USAAF?|date=March 2010}} the 1st camouflaged "modified" site,{{Rp|8}} and 12 more were identified within days. {{cite journal |date=October 28, 1957 |title=V-Bomb Photo Search |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5lYEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA143 |journal=Life magazine |page=143 |accessdate=2010-02-12}} [[V-1 flying bomb (facilities)#V-1 launching sites|The V-1 launch site design had been modified]] for simplicity and to use transportable catapult sections, making them "''more difficult to discover and easy to replace''", bombing more difficult, and completion time relatively short when V-1 supplies were sufficient. [[Operation Crossbow|Crossbow]] continued bombing the obsolete and heavily damaged "ski sites" due to a German [[deception|ruse]] to portray they were being repaired.{{Rp|3}} Additionally, espionage became more difficult as only German & prisoner/[[forced labor]] was used for "modified" sites instead of the previously-used French construction firms. |- | 1944-04 | [[Mittelwerk]] |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] An intelligence report identified "''Sixty flat cars left the plant; three cars had two rockets each in them.''" Reports came from 2 Polish laborers of the [[Mittelbau-Dora]] camp. {{cite book |last=Garliński|first=Józef|authorlink=Józef Garliński|title=Hitler's Last Weapons: The Underground War against the V1 and V2|year=1978|publisher=Times Books|location=New York|pages=52, 82}}{{Rp|52}} |- | 1944-05-05 | Poland |{{sort|PR1944-05-05|}}[[File:Flag of Poland.svg|20px]] PR of "the flying bomb compound" at Blizna contained an image of a rocket that R. V. Jones subsequently recognized on July 17. |- | 1944-06-06 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] |{{sort|PR1944-06-06|}}61 modified sites had been photographed,{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} and 83 of 96 ski sites had been destroyed (only 2 of the ski sites launched V-1s).{{Rp|32,75}} |- | 1944-06-10 | [[History of Belgium#World War II|Belgium]] |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] A Belgian agent reported 33 railcars (carrying 99 V-1s) had passed through [[Ghent]]. |- | 1944-06-11 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] [[Vignacourt]] |{{sort|PR1944-06-11|}}[[File:RAF roundel.svg|12px]] PR showed the Vignacourt modified site was being completed, which allowed image interpreters to predict sites would be ready to launch V-1s{{Rp|174d}} within 3 days{{Cite book |last=Gurney |first=Gene (Major, USAF) |year=1962 |title=The War in the Air: a pictorial history of World War II Air Forces in combat |location=New York |publisher=Bonanza Books |page=184}} |- | 1944-06-11 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] [[Saleux]] |{{sort|PR1944-06-11|}}66 modified sites had been photographed.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} On the 13th just after midnight, the [[Saleux]] site launched the first combat V-1 ([[Hans Kammler]] visited the Saleux V-1 site on August 10).{{Rp|258d}} |- | {{sort|1944-06-15|1944-06}} | [[RAF Medmenham]] |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] A special Medmenham [[Aerial photographic and satellite image interpretation|image interpretation]] section for site photographs was set up for [[Duncan Sandys]]. |- | 1944-06-13 | {{sort|Sweden|}}[[File:Flag of Sweden.svg|20px]] | Stray test V2 rocket explodes over [[Bäckebo]] Sweden, fired from Peenemünde and aimed at Baltic sea outside island of Bornholm, but overshoots the target area and lands in south Sweden. Remains are shipped to the UK [http://www.nyteknik.se/nyheter/fordon_motor/article3208141.ece]. |- | 1944-06-17 | Poland |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] [[File:Flag of Poland.svg|20px]] An intel report identified apparatus 17053 was sent to Peenemünde from Blizna—launches of [[Mittelwerk]] V-2s [[List of V-2 test launches|17001-17100 (January–April) were at both Peenemünde and Blizna]]. |- | 1944-06-30 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] |{{sort|UKUS|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] [[File:US flag 48 stars.svg|20px]] Anglo-American Intelligence had identified [[Nucourt]] and [[Saint-Leu-d'Esserent]] were [[V-1 flying bomb (facilities)|underground V-1 storage]].{{cite book |last=Collier |first=Basil |year=1976 |origyear=1964 |title=The Battle of the V-Weapons, 1944-1945 |location=Yorkshire |publisher=The Emfield Press |pages=68,82,84,103 |isbn=0-7057-0070-4}} On June 15, 55 sites were launching V-1s,{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} and in July, 38 sites launched 316 V-1s over a 24-hour period (25 crashed at launch).{{Rp|81}} By July 10, [[Arthur Tedder]] had assigned 30 [[Operation Crossbow|Crossbow targets]] to [[Sir Arthur Harris, 1st Baronet|Arthur Harris]]' [[RAF Bomber Command]], 6 to [[AEAF]] tactical airforce, and 68 to [[Carl Spaatz]]' [[USSTAF]].{{cite book |last=Mets |first=David R. |year=1997|edition=paperback|origyear=1988 |title=Master of Airpower: General Carl A. Spaatz |page=239}} Code named NOBALL, the targets numbered as high as 147 (i.e., "no ball V1 site No.147, {{sic|[[Ligescourt|Ligercourt]]}}").{{cite book |last=Clostermann |first=Pierre |authorlink=Pierre Clostermann |year=2004 |title=The Big Show |url=http://www.checksix-fr.com/bibliotheque/index.php?page=detail&ID=5046 |location=London |publisher=Weidenfeld & Nicolson |isbn=0-297-84619-1 |accessdate=2010-03-15}} |- | 1944-07-16 | |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] A report misidentified the likely rocket fuel was [[hydrogen peroxide]] ([[T-Stoff]]), and [[File:US roundel 1942-1943.svg|12px]][[Bombing of Peenemünde in World War II|attacks were conducted on suspected sources]]. |- | 1944-07-18 |{{sort|France|}}[[File:Flag of France.svg|20px]] |{{sort|Z|}}[[File:Flag of Germany 1933.svg|20px]] [[Adolf Hitler]] ruled the V-2 launch bunker plans could be abandoned.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} To reduce the risk of espionage and counterattacks, [[Meillerwagen|mobile firing batteries]] were subsequently used for [[Shoot-and-scoot|launching and then leaving the site]]. {{cite book |last=Huzel|first=Dieter K|title=Peenemünde to Canaveral|year=1960|publisher=Prentice Hall|location=Englewood Cliffs NJ|page=93}} An alternate concealment plan for firing V-2s just outside railway tunnels (code named [[Meillerwagen|Regenwurm]]) was also abandoned, as was an earlier plan that had constructed fixed concrete launch pads in clearings of Northern France. |- | 1944-07 | [[Wright Field]] |{{sort|US|}}[[File:US flag 48 stars.svg|20px]] Experts fired a V-1 engine [[Reverse engineering|reconstructed]] from "[[The Blitz#V-Weapons offensive|Robot Blitz]]" wreckage{{Rp|174b}} (an entire V-1 was reconstructed at [[Republic Aviation]] by September 8).U.S. Air Force Tactical Missiles, (2009), George Mindling, Robert Bolton {{ISBN|978-0-557-00029-6}}{{Verify source||date=March 2009}} |- | 1944-07-21 | |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] The British inaccurately interpreted the July 18–21 effort of 50 air-launched V-1s had been "ground-launched" from the [[Low Countries]], particularly near [[Ostend]].{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} |- | 1944-07-22{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} | ===Big Ben=== |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] [[Royal Aircraft Establishment|Experts]] at [[Farnborough Airfield|Farnborough]] issued a report on [[Sweden during World War II#The Bäckebo Bomb|June 13 V-2 wreckage from Sweden]] for which the UK agreed to exchange [[Supermarine Spitfires|Spitfires]].{{Rp|103}} The lack of lubricant in the wreckage's turbopump indicated cooling by a pumped liquefied gas, and intelligence reports about [[liquid oxygen]] as rocket fuel allowed the accurate interpretation that the payload was 2 tons or less. Conversely, the British mistakenly prepared [[Radio jamming|radio jammers]] since the wreckage happened to have [[Wasserfall]] guidance control for a test (only a small portion of combat V-2s used radio motor cutoff—during ascent and with a 10 km interference range from the "firing point"). The test was for determining "''the [[Electric field screening|influence of the rocket jet on the guidance radio signal.]]''"{{Rp|100}} |- | 1944-07-28{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} | '''Big Ben''' |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] Eight V-2 parts from Poland along with photographs, drawings, and ''Special Report 1/R no. 242'' arrived in the UK from [[Brindisi]], Italy. In [[Operation Most III]] an RAF [[C-47 Skytrain|Dakota]] had landed at an abandoned German airfield in Poland on July 25/26 and collected the {{convert|100|lb|abbr=on}} of cargo from the Polish underground.{{Rp|158,173}} The Polish parts came from V-2s launched from Blizna (one had crashed near Sarnaki without exploding on May 20), and [[Home Army and V1 and V2|the underground]] had hidden wreckage in the [[Western Bug]] river.{{cite book |last=McGovern |first=James |year=1964 |title=Crossbow and [[Operation Paperclip|Overcast]] |publisher=W. Morrow |location=New York |page=71,74}}{{Rp|71}} [[Antoni Kocjan]] prepared the Polish parts and information, which arrived after the British had already obtained similar material from the Swedish V-2 wreckage (as did Sanders' Blizna report). Most III also transported{{Clarify|which way?|date=July 2011}} Jerzy Chmielewski, who had cycled 200 miles through enemy territory and reported the [[V-2#Airburst problem|V-2 airbursts]] to the British.{{Rp|444}} |- | 1944-07-31 | [[Meillerwagen]] |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] A dummy rocket and an erector trailer captured at a V-2 storage site at [[Hautmesnil]] confirmed the size of the V-2.{{Rp|446}} |- | 1944-08-15 | [[Double Cross System]] |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] Use of [[double agents]] to deceive the [[Luftwaffe]] into [[wiktionary:mis-|mis-aiming]] the V-1s continued despite risking civilians in one area over others. After the last V-1 launch in France on September 1, Canadian troops captured the last of the initial V-1 launch sites.{{cite book |last=Henshall|first=Phillip|title=Hitler’s Rocket Sites|year=1985|location=New York |publisher=St Martin's Press|pages=64,111}} Despite intelligence and [[Operation Crossbow|countermeasures]], V-1s killed/seriously injured over 6,000/17,000 UK civilians, even when only ~1/4 of the V-1s launched at England struck successfully.{{Rp|42}} Over 8000 V-1s were launched at London{{cite book |last=von Braun |first=Wernher |authorlink=Wernher von Braun |author2=[[Frederick I. Ordway III|Ordway III, Frederick I]] |author3=Dooling, David Jr |title=Space Travel: A History |location=New York |publisher=Harper & Row |year=1985|edition=first |origyear=1975 |isbn=0-06-181898-4 |page=105}} (2,448 at Antwerp){{Rp|82}}—2340 reached the London Civil Defence Region from France,{{cite book |last=Collier |first=Basil |editor=Butler, J. R. M. |year=1995 |origyear=1957 |title=The Defence of the United Kingdom |series=[[History of the Second World War#United Kingdom Military Series|United Kingdom Military Series]] |publisher=[[aOffice of Public Sector Information|Her Majesty's Stationery Office]] |isbn=1-870423-09-7}} (cited as the "[[History of the Second World War|Official History]]" by Jones, p. 423) and by June 27 in the UK,{{Verify source|WHAT LOCATION DOES D Eisenhower SPECIFY?|date=March 2010}} "''over 200,000 houses had been damaged or destroyed by the V-1… and shattered sewage systems threatened serious epidemics.''"{{cite book |last=Eisenhower |first=David |authorlink=David Eisenhower |year=1991 |origyear=1986 |title=Eisenhower: At War 1943-1945 |location=New York |publisher=Wings Books |page=349 |isbn=0-517-06501-0 |quote=Of the 10,500 V-I's launched at England, an estimated 25 percent flew off course because of malfunction. Roughly 20 percent penetrated British defenses and hit targets, claiming 10,000 lives and 1.1 million homes}} |- | 1944-08-25 | |{{sort|UKUS|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] [[File:US flag 48 stars.svg|20px]] Plans for [[aerial reconnaissance]] of V-2 sites were included{{cite web |last=Gruen |first=Adam L |title=Preemptive Defense, Allied Air Power Versus Hitler’s V-Weapons, 1943–1945 |url=http://www.usaaf.net/ww2/preemptivedefense |work=The U.S. Army Air Forces in World War II |pages=4(Round 1),5(Round 2) |accessdate=2007-05-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090705002929/http://www.usaaf.net/ww2/preemptivedefense/ |archive-date=2009-07-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }}{{Rp|37}} in the joint "Plan for Attack on the German Rocket Organization When Rocket Attacks Commence".{{cite book |editor-last=Craven |editor-first=Wesley Frank |editor2=Cate, James Lea |title=(Volume 3) Europe: Argument to V-E Day |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jTXWGhwBacAC&pg=PA530 |format=[[Google Books]] |work=The Army Air Forces in World War II|page=535 }} Based on rocket fuel intelligence the plan also identified primary and secondary liquid-oxygen plants as the third priority targets{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}
[[File:US roundel 1942-1943.svg|12px]] Mission 572 on August 24 had targeted rocket fuel production in France and Belgium. |- | 1944-08-25 | Belgium |{{sort|USAAF|}}[[File:US roundel 1942-1943.svg|12px]] Based on the intelligence of V-2 [[liquid oxygen]], the [[Eighth Air Force]] bombed 5 LOX plants (the next day's mission was "to hit liquid oxygen plants at [[La Louvière]], Torte and [[Willebroek]]"). |- | 1944-09-08 | [[Sound ranging]] |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] Microphones in [[East Kent]] reported the times of the first London V-2s: 18:40:52 and 18:41:08 (at different locations, both Jones and [[Duncan Sandys]] recognized the supersonic "double-crack").{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} The [[Sound ranging#World War II|ranging system]] provided the V-2 "''trajectory from which the general launching area could be determined''."{{Rp|251}} [[Civil defense]] officials refused to give any public information about the rocket ("It might have been a gas main explosion"), and despite that day's German headline—"[[Vergeltungswaffe]]-2 Gegen London im Einsatz" ({{lang-en|Vengeance Weapon 2 in Action Against London}}){{Rp|119}}—the British's official SECRET statement was that "BIG BEN" had not been "CONFIRMED".{{cite book |last=Johnson |first=David |year=1982 |title=V-1, V-2: Hitler's Vengeance on London |publisher=Stein and Day |pages=117, 130}} |- | 1944-09-17 | [[History of the Netherlands (1939–1945)|Netherlands]] |{{sort|RAF|}}[[File:RAF roundel.svg|12px]] [[Airfield]]s suspected as [[Heinkel He 111|He 111]] bases for V-1 air-launches were attacked{{Rp|37}} (airfields were bombed at Hopsten, [[Leeuwarden]], [[Steenwijk]], and [[Rheine]]). [[File:Roundel of the German Air Force (with Border).svg|12px]][[V-1 flying bomb#Experimental and long-range variants|Modified V-1s]] were air-launched from September 16-January 14 (865 launches). {{cite book |last=Pocock|first=Rowland F|title=German Guided Missiles of the Second World War|year=1967|publisher=Arco Publishing Company, Inc.|location=New York|page=104}}{{Rp|104}} On October 21, the first V-1 launches for [[Operation Donnerschlag]] ({{lang-en|Thunderclap}}) began from Germany.{{Rp|46}} |- | 1944-09-22 | Poland |{{sort|UKUS|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] [[File:US flag 48 stars.svg|20px]] [[File:Flag of Poland.svg|20px]] After the Soviets captured Blizna in July and the Anglo-American Sanders Mission arrived on September 3, [[Terence Sanders|Colonel T.R.B Sanders]] issued his preliminary report. |- | {{sort|1944-10-15|1944-10}} | Mittelwerk |{{sort|PR1944-10-15|}}PR of [[Niedersachswerfen]] showed shadows of railcars consistent with those loaded with V-2s. |- | 1944-10-25 | Netherlands |{{sort|UKUS|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] An informant arrived behind Allied lines with reports of V-2 launches from [[Wassenaar]]. |- | 1944-12 | [[Royal Artillery]] |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] [[Fireworks (disambiguation)#Other|Project Firework]] was enacted by the [[Army Group Royal Artillery|11th Survey Regiment]] to watch for "all data obtained regarding the origin and flight of enemy rockets" with the use of [[sound ranging]] stations and, after modification, [[History of radar#United Kingdom|the radar stations]] at Swingate, Rye, Pevensey, Poling, and Ventnor (11 Group); and Branscombe, Ringstead, and Southbourne (10 Group) along with the pair at St Lawrence and Newchurch.{{Rp|56, 157}} Radar allowed [[London Passenger Transport Board|London Transport]] to be warned when the predicted impact (5 mile accuracy) was near the [[Tower Subway|Thames subway tunnels]]. |- | 1944-12-31 ===1945=== | Netherlands |{{sort|UK|}}[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] At the home of 14 yr old Hans van Wouw Koeleman, who observed and reported{{Clarify|reported to who?|date=July 2011}} a few Dutch coast launches of V-2s, his father toasted the "favourable results the Germans had achieved that night" when a V-2 launch just prior to midnight "to wish Londoners a Happy New Year" failed and hit a German barracks.{{Rp|133,177}} |- | 1945-02-08 | Peenemünde |{{sort|PR1945-02-08|}}[[File:Flag of the Soviet Union (1936-1955).svg|20px]] Ten Soviet prisoners led by [[Mikhail Devyatayev]] escape from the concentration camp on [[Usedom]] by stealing the camp commander's plane, which contained special equipment for tracking V-2 launches. They tell how Germans hide V-2 launch sites on the island using movable trees.{{cite book|last1=Mikhail|first1=Devi︠a︡taev|title=Pobeg iz ada : Na samolete vraga iz nemet︠s︡ko-fashistskogo plena|date=2015|publisher=Moskva : Obshchestvo sokhranenii︠a︡ literaturnogo nasledii︠a︡|location=Moscow, Russia|isbn=9785902484721|lccn=2016454013|language=Russian}} |- | 1945-03-20 | Netherlands |{{sort|PR1945-03-20|}}[[File:RAF roundel.svg|12px]] After PR showed V-1 sites at [[Ypenburg]] and [[Vlaardingen]], an [[RAF Fighter Command]] squadron attacked the former, while on the 23rd the [[RAF Second Tactical Air Force]] attacked the latter.{{Rp|133–6}} |- | 1945-03 | [[Operation Paperclip]] |{{sort|US|}}A Polish laboratory technician found pieces of the [[Operation Paperclip#The Osenberg List|Osenberg List]] of German scientists in a toilet at [[University of Bonn|Bonn University]].{{Rp|104}} The [[Ordnance Corps (United States Army)]] used the Osenberg List to compile the list of rocket scientists to be captured and interrogated ([[Wernher von Braun]]'s name was at the top).{{Rp|314}} |- | 1945-04-11 | Mittelwerk |{{sort|US|}}[[File:US flag 48 stars.svg|20px]] After intel had said to "expect something a little unusual" at [[Nordhausen]], the Army found the underground factory rockets, the dead [[Mittelbau-Dora|Boelcke Kaserne]] [[forced labor]]ers, and the evacuated [[Dora concentration camp]]. In June 1945, a mission led by the British engineer [[Roy Fedden]] inspected the factory. Earlier 1944 technical inspections included one by [[Frédéric Joliot-Curie]] and [[Duncan Sandys]] to Watten on September 10 and one by Colonel T.R.B. Sanders to [[La Coupole|Wizernes]] in November. Similarly in July 1944, both Eisenhower and Churchill had visited the [[Brécourt]] bunker – the latter reportedly dropping an apple he was eating in astonishment of the massive facility.{{cite web |language=French |last=Maridor |first=Jean |title= Le site V1 de Cherbourg Brécourt |url=http://www.jean-maridor.org/francais/brecourt.htm |work= Les bombes volantes V1 |accessdate=2008-02-27|publisher=}} |- |} The day after Strategic Bombing Directive No. 4 ended the strategic air war in Europe, the use of radar was discontinued in the [[Historical and alternative regions of England#World War II|London Civil Defence Region]] for detecting V-2 launches. The last launches had been on March 27 (V-2) and March 29 (V-1 flying bomb). ==References== ;Notes {{reflist|26em}} ;Bibliography {{cite book |last=Jones |first=R. V. |authorlink=Reginald Victor Jones |year=1978 |title=Most Secret War: British Scientific Intelligence 1939-1945 |location=London |publisher=Hamish Hamilton |isbn=0-241-89746-7}} {{V-weapons}} [[Category:V-weapons]] [[Category:Technical intelligence during World War II]] [[Category:Nazi-related lists]] [[Category:German military-related lists]] [[Category:World War II-related lists]]

{{no footnotes|date=October 2016}}
'''Vacuum cooling''' is known to be the most rapid [[cooling]] technique{{cn|date=October 2016}} for any [[porous]] product which has free water and works on the principle of [[evaporative cooling]]. Vacuum cooling is generally used for cooling food products having a high water content and large porosities, due to its efficacy in losing water from both within and outside the products. This is the most widely used technique for rapid cooling of food product which has been proven to be one of the most efficient and economical method of cooling and storage of vegetables, fruits, flowers & more.{{cn|date=October 2016}}
This cooling technology not only strongly improves the product quality, but also increases the [[shelf life]] of product and at the same time it reduces the cooling costs compared to the conventional cooling method available.{{cn|date=October 2016}}
==Principle== The technology is based on the phenomenon that as the [[vapour pressure]] on a liquid reduces, its [[boiling point]] reduces. The boiling point of a liquid is defined as the temperature at which the vapour pressure of the liquid is equal to the external pressure. When the pressure above a liquid is reduced, the vapour pressure needed to induce boiling is also reduced, and the boiling point of the liquid decreases. By reducing pressure we can even boil off water at lower temperatures. This rapid evaporation of moisture from the surface and within the products due to the low surrounding pressure, absorbs the necessary [[latent heat]] for [[Phase transition|phase change]] from the product itself. This latent heat required for evaporation is obtained mostly from the [[sensible heat]] of the product and as a consequence of this evaporation the temperature of the product falls and the product can be cooled down to its desired [[storage temperature]].
==Process== An airtight chamber is maintained by removing air from the inside of the chamber using a [[vacuum pump]]. The products to be cooled are kept in that airtight chamber. As the pressure is reduced the boiling point of water reduces and water starts to evaporate, taking the heat from the product. As a consequence of this evaporation the product temperature begins to decrease. This cooling process of the products continues until it reaches the desired product temperature.
For maintaining steady cooling process, it is necessary to evacuate the chamber continuously.
Other factors that determine the cooling process are surface area of product, available for [[heat transfer]] and also the product sensitivity during losing water.
==Advantages== As the product is cooled uniformly throughout the body without any temperature gradient in the body, the shelf life of the product increases.
==Disadvantage== Sometimes excess moisture loss during the cooling process will deteriorate the product quality and therefore there is a limit to the cooling process. This problem is to be taken care of by maintaining the required pressure, temperature and time of cooling.
==References== * H.M. Ozturk, H.K. Ozturk, Effect of pressure on the vacuum cooling of iceberg lettuce Int. J. Refrig. Revue Int. Du. Froid, 32 (3) (2009), pp. 402–410 * {{cite journal| journal=Critical Reviews in Food Science and Nutrition |volume=52|issue=11|year=2012 |title=Vacuum Cooling of Meat Products: Current State-of-the-Art Research Advances|doi=10.1080/10408398.2011.594186}} * http://issuu.com/coldmax/docs/coldmax_web_uk/1 * http://vacuumcooling.eu/vacuum-cooling-benefits/
[[Category:Cooling technology]] [[Category:Applied and interdisciplinary physics]] [[Category:Engineering thermodynamics]] [[Category:Industrial gases]] [[Category:Food preservation]]

page.title: We choose to go to the Moon

revision.comment: Reverted 4 edits by [[Special:Contributions/Gshah053|Gshah053]] ([[User talk:Gshah053|talk]]) to last revision by Andy Dingley. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=January 2016}} {{imagestack| [[Image:Wimshurst.jpg|thumb|Wimshurst machine with two [[Leyden jar]]s.]] [[Image:WimshurstElectricMachine.jpg|thumb|Suppose that the conditions are as in the figure, with the segment A1 positive and the segment B1 negative. Now, as A1 moves to the left and B1 to the right, their potentials will rise on account of the work done in separating them against attraction. When A1 and neighboring sectors comes opposite the segment B2 of the B plate, which is now in contact with the brush Y, they will cause a displacement of electricity along the conductor between Y and Y1 bringing a negative charge, larger than the positive charge in A1 alone, on Y and sending a positive charge to the segment touching Y1. As A1 moves on, it passes near the brush Z and is partially discharged into the external circuit. It then passes on until, on touching the brush X, has a new charge, this time negative, driven into it by induction from B2 and neighboring sectors. As the machine turns, the process causes exponential increases in the voltages on all positions, until sparking occurs limiting the increase.]] [[Image:Wimshurst Machine VGA.webm|thumb|Wimshurst machine at work]] }}
The '''Wimshurst influence machine''' is an [[electrostatic generator]], a machine for generating high [[voltage]]s developed between 1880 and 1883 by [[United Kingdom|British]] [[inventor]] [[James Wimshurst]] (1832–1903).
It has a distinctive appearance with two large contra-rotating discs mounted in a vertical plane, two crossed bars with metallic brushes, and a [[spark gap]] formed by two metal spheres.
==Description== These machines belong to a class of electrostatic generators called [[influence machine]]s, which separate [[electric charge]]s through [[electrostatic induction]], or ''influence'', not depending on friction for their operation. Earlier machines in this class were developed by [[Wilhelm Holtz]] (1865 and 1867), [[August Toepler]] (1865), J. Robert Voss (1880), and others. The older machines are less efficient and exhibit an unpredictable tendency to switch their polarity. The Wimshurst does not have this defect.
In a Wimshurst machine, the two insulated discs and their metal sectors rotate in opposite directions passing the crossed metal neutralizer bars and their brushes. An imbalance of charges is induced, amplified, and collected by two pairs of metal combs with points placed near the surfaces of each disk. These collectors are mounted on insulating supports and connected to the output terminals. The positive feedback increases the accumulating charges exponentially until the dielectric breakdown voltage of the air is reached and an [[electric spark]] jumps across the gap.
The machine is theoretically not self-starting, meaning that if none of the sectors on the discs has any electrical charge there is nothing to induce charges on other sectors. In practice, even a small residual charge on any sector is enough to start the process going once the discs start to rotate. The machine will only work satisfactorily in a dry atmosphere. It requires mechanical [[power (physics)|power]] to turn the disks against the electric field, and it is this energy that the machine converts into the electric power of the spark. The steady state output of the Wimshurst machine is a direct (non-alternating) [[current (electricity)|current]] that is proportional to the area covered by the metal sector, the rotation speed, and a complicated function of the initial charge distribution. The insulation and the size of the machine determine the maximum output voltage that can be reached. The accumulated spark energy can be increased by adding a pair of [[Leyden jar]]s, an early type of [[capacitor]] suitable for high voltages, with the jars’ inner plates independently connected to each of the output terminals and the jars’ outer plates interconnected. A typical Wimshurst machine can produce sparks that are about a third of the disc's diameter in length and several tens of microamperes.
The available voltage gain can be understood by noting that the charge density on oppositely charged sectors, between the neutralizer bars, is nearly uniform across the sectors, and thus at low voltage, while the charge density on same charged sectors, approaching the collector combs, peaks near the sector edges, at a consequently high voltage relative to the opposite collector combs.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}
Wimshurst machines were used during the 19th century in physics research. They were also occasionally used to generate high voltage to power the first-generation Crookes [[X-ray tube]]s during the first two decades of the 20th century, although [[Electrostatic generator#Holtz_machine|Holtz machines]] and [[induction coil]]s were more commonly used. Today they are only used in science museums and education to demonstrate the principles of electrostatics.
==Operation== The two contra-rotating insulating discs (usually made of glass) have a number of metal sectors stuck onto them. The machine is provided with four small earthed brushes (two on each side of the machine on conducting shafts at 90° to each other), plus a pair of charge-collection combs. The conducting shafts, that hold the brushes on a typical Wimshurst machine, would form the shape of an "X", if one could see through the insulating disks, as they are perpendicular to each other. The charge-collection combs are typically mounted along the horizontal and equally contact the outer edges of both front and back discs. The collection combs on each side are usually connected to respective [[Leyden jar]]s.
[[File:Wimshurst Machine Charge Cycle.gif|frame|center|Animation]]
Any small charge on either of the two discs suffices to begin the charging process. Suppose, therefore, that the back disc has a small, net electrostatic charge. For concreteness, assume this charge is positive (red) and that the back disc ([A] lower chain) rotates counter-clockwise (right to left). As the charged sector (moving red square) rotates to the position of the brush ([Y] down arrow tip) next to front disc ([B] upper chain near center), it induces a polarization of charge on the conducting shaft ([Y-Y1] upper horizontal black line) holding the brush, attracting negative (green) charge to the near side ([Y] upper square becoming green), so that positive (red) charge accumulates on the far side (across the disc, 180 degrees away) ([Y1] upper square becoming red). The shaft's polarized charges attach to the nearest sectors on disc B, resulting in negative charge on B [Y] closer to the original positive charge on A, and positive charge on the opposite side of B [Y1]. After an additional 45° rotation ([Z] near lower chain middle), the positive (red) charge on A (lower chain) is repelled by a positive (red) charge on B ([Z] upper chain) approaching. The first collection comb ([Z] arrow-tipped lines to triangles) encountered allows both positive (red) charges to leave the sectors neutral (squares becoming black), and accumulate in the Leyden jar anode (red triangle) attracted to the Leyden jar cathode (green triangle). The charge completes the cycle across the discs when a spark (yellow zigzag) discharges the Leyden jar (red and green triangles).
As B rotates 90° clockwise (left to right), the charges that have been induced on it line up with the brushes next to disc A [X, X1]. The charges on B induce the opposite polarization of the A-brushes' shaft, and the shaft's polarization is transferred to its disc. Disc B keeps rotating and its charges are accumulated by the nearest charge-collection combs.
Disc A rotates 90° so that its charges line up with the brush of disc B [Y, Y1], where an opposite charge-polarization is induced on the B conducting shaft and the nearest sectors of B, similar to the description two paragraphs above.
The process repeats, with each charge polarization on A inducing polarization on B, inducing polarization on A, etc. All of these induced positive and negative charges are collected by combs to charge the Leyden jars, electrical charge-storage devices similar to capacitors. The mechanical energy required to separate the opposing charges on the adjacent sectors provides the energy source for the electrical output.
